to work too much, often to the point of exhaustion or burnout

to spend a lot of money on something trivial that one does not really need
to give someone the money one owes
to contribute or pay the required amount in order to settle and clear a debt

to return an amount of money that was borrowed
to make payment to someone for the service they have provided

to use a property, asset, or item in exchange for regular payments of money
to buy houses, shares, lands, etc. with the hope of gaining a profit
to get goods or services from an external supplier or assign specific tasks to an outside entity rather than handling them internally

to sell small quantities of goods directly to customers
to gain something good from something or someone
to gain money or material benefits
to sell goods, typically in a public place or through a vending machine

to sell something one has previously purchased

to provide with a supply of something, such as goods or inventory, for use or sale
to enthusiastically promote or advertise something, emphasizing its positive qualities to attract attention or interest

to earn total income before subtracting expenses or taxes
to set an amount that is needed as payment for a product or a service

to earn a lot of money or resources through successful efforts or actions

title: Verbs Related to Recreation and Sports

data.translation: to take a period of time off from work or daily activities to relax and engage in leisure activities
to have a meal or social gathering outdoors
to visit interesting and well-known places
to do something special such as dancing or drinking that shows one is happy for an event
to move the body to music in a special way
to use one's voice in order to produce musical sounds in the form of a tune or song
to lie or sit in the sun in order to darken one's skin
to take part in a game or activity for fun
to risk money on the result of a coming event by trying to predict it
to take part in games of chance or betting, involving money, hoping to win more in return
to play with small numbered objects, often used in games of chance or for fun
to engage in a physical competition involving holds, maneuvers, and grappling, often as part of a sport or for recreation
to jump out of an airplane and experience free-fall before safely descending using a parachute
to do physical activities or sports to stay healthy and become stronger
to move on ice or other smooth surfaces using ice skates, roller skates, or a skateboard
to slide down snow-covered slopes using a flat board with bindings attached to boots

to enjoy and immerse oneself in a rhythm or activity

to express one's good wishes or praise to someone when something very good has happened to them
to be the organizer of an event such as a meeting, party, etc. to which people are invited
to go somewhere with someone

to celebrate or engage in lively and festive social activities, often with a group of people
to interact and spend time with people
to show someone the important parts of a place by walking through it together
to invite someone to enter a place, often a room, office, house, etc.
to receive someone as a guest at one's home
to accompany someone to the exit when they are departing
to socialize, often in a friendly or familiar manner, especially with people of influence or importance
to spend much time in a specific place or with someone particular
to be contacted by a person or an entity, usually by letter, email, or phone call

title: Verbs Related to Medicine and Health

data.translation: to become healthy again
to make someone regain their health
to provide medical care such as medicine or therapy to heal injuries, illnesses, or wounds and make someone better
to regain complete health after a period of sickness or injury
to recover from an unpleasant or unhappy experience, particularly an illness
to find out the cause of a problem or disease that a person has by examining the symptoms
to transmit a disease to a person, animal, or plant
to insert a substance or material into the body, often through a needle

to carefully cut apart the body or one of its parts to display internal structures for scientific examination or instruction
to send someone to hospital for medical treatment
to insert a living tissue or an artificial object into the body via medical procedure
to provide care and support to individuals who are sick or handicapped, aiding in their recovery or well-being
to help someone to restore to a healthy and independent state after a period of imprisonment, addiction, illness, etc.
to protect an animal or a person from a disease by vaccination
to give a calming substance to a person or animal, often for medical reasons or to reduce anxiety
to give a substance to a person or animal, typically for medical reasons
to surgically remove a body part, such as a limb or organ, often due to injury, disease, or medical necessity
to start experiencing symptoms of an illness
to become affected by an illness
to protect a person or an animal against a disease by giving them a preventive shot against specific diseases
to eject what has been eaten or drunk through the mouth
to attempt to vomit but be unable to, typically due to an unpleasant taste or smell
to forcibly expel the contents of the stomach through the mouth
to expel the contents of the stomach through the mouth
to push air out of our mouth with a sudden noise
to blow air out of our nose and mouth in a sudden way
to feel a sensation on the skin that makes one want to scratch
to feel a prolonged physical pain in a part of one's body, especially one that is not severe
to lose blood from an injury or wound
to suddenly lose consciousness from a lack of oxygen in the brain, which is caused by a shock, etc.
(of a person) to fall and usually become unconscious due to illness
to lose consciousness
to awaken from a state of unconsciousness
to breathe with difficulty, especially with a whistling or rattling sound
to become rounder or larger, particularly due to an increase in the amount of fluid

title: Verbs Related to the Legal System

data.translation: to cause someone suffering for breaking the law or having done something they should not have
to officially state the punishment of someone found guilty in a court of law
to say something is the case without providing proof for it
to formally say that someone has done something wrong or illegal, often involving making specific charges against them
to bring a charge against an individual or organization in a law court
to release someone until their trial after they gave an amount of money to the court
to give someone the legal right to have or do something particular
to try to charge someone officially with a crime in a court as the lawyer of the accuser
to approve a proposed law
to officially cancel a law, regulation, or policy, making it no longer valid or in effect
to formally charge or accuse someone of a crime or misdemeanor
to officially accuse someone of an offense
to officially accuse a person of a crime
to put someone in prison or keep them somewhere and not let them go
to put someone in a designated facility either as punishment or while waiting for legal proceedings
to restrict someone's freedom by confining them, often done for security, control, or public safety reasons
to confine someone in prison or a similar facility due to legal reasons or as a form of punishment
to officially decide and declare in a law court that someone is not guilty of a crime
to initiate legal action against another party or person
to make a formal decision or judgment about who is right in an argument or dispute
to make something legally valid
to formally object or challenge a judge's participation in a case, often due to concerns about their impartiality or potential conflicts of interest
to impose a punishment on someone for a wrongdoing or violation
to officially summon someone to attend a court proceeding, produce evidence, or provide testimony under penalty of law
to permit something by law, granting people the right or freedom to do it
to create or bring laws into effect through a formal process
to no longer be able to access a right, property, privilege, etc. as a result of violating a law or a punishment for doing something wrong
to make a statement as a witness in court saying something is true
(of law enforcement agencies) to take a person away because they believe that they have done something illegal
to arrest someone
to announce officially that someone is guilty of a crime in a court of law
to question someone in an aggressive way for a long time in order to get information
to oversee and enforce laws, regulations, or safety measures in a specific area, typically carried out by law enforcement or responsible authorities
to regularly move through a designated area, such as streets or neighborhoods, to ensure safety, security, and adherence to rules
to restrain a person's hands together using a device, commonly done by law enforcement during an arrest
to restrain someone by securing their wrists together, often using a device, commonly done by law enforcement during an arrest or to maintain control
to officially take away something from someone, usually as punishment
to temporarily take possession of something, typically by legal authority, as a measure of security or due to a violation
to catch someone because they are suspected of doing something wrong
to give someone or something to the authorities or the person in charge
to admit, especially to the police or legal authorities, that one has committed a crime or has done something wrong
to unlawfully and intentionally kill another human being
to make secret plans with other people to commit an illegal or destructive act
to take something from someone or somewhere without permission or paying for it
to take something from an organization, place, etc. without their consent, or with force
to take someone away and hold them in captivity, typically to demand something for their release
to illegally take someone away, especially by force or deception
to steal goods from a place or person, especially during times of war, chaos, or civil disorder
to forcefully take control of a vehicle, like an airplane, often to take hostages or change its course
to steal from someone by threatening them or using violence, particularly in a public place

to illegally hunt, catch, or fish on another person's property or in prohibited areas
to illegally trade something
to move goods or people illegally and secretly into or out of a country
to illegally obtain or exploit copyrighted or patented material for personal gain
to persuade someone to do something, often illegal, by giving them an amount of money or something of value
to provide evidence or information that suggests a person's involvement in a crime or wrongdoing
to involve or suggest someone's participation or connection in a crime or wrongdoing
to disobey or break a regulation, an agreement, etc.
to break an agreement, law, etc.
to violate someone's rights or property
to use force to enter a building, vehicle, or other enclosed space, usually for the purpose of theft
to rob someone using a weapon or some form of threat
to escape punishment for one's wrong actions
to illegally enter a building or area with the intent to commit theft or other crimes
to secretly steal money entrusted to one's care, typically by manipulating financial records, for personal use or gain
to steal goods from a store by secretly taking them without paying
to intentionally damage something, particularly public property

title: Verbs Related to Conflict and Military Actions

data.translation: to begin using weapons against a place or enemy during a war
(of police) to unexpectedly visit a person or place to arrest suspects or find illegal goods
to take part in a violent physical action against someone
(of military) to move away in order to escape the danger because one has been defeated or is weak
to join the armed forces
(of a state) to organize and prepare for a military operation
to gather individuals, like military or jury duty personnel, to fulfill their assigned duties
to adapt or use something, like technology or resources, for the purpose of creating a weapon or strengthening military capabilities
to provide individuals or groups with weapons, ensuring they have the necessary equipment for defense or offense
to deprive someone or something of weapons or the ability to cause harm
to carry out a sudden and intense military attack

to aim to shoot at or attack a certain person or thing
to direct or guide something such as a weapon at a person or thing
to attack someone or something using explosive devices
to shoot a bullet, shell, etc. from a weapon
to release a bullet or arrow from a gun or bow
to not hit or touch what was aimed at
to drop bombs on someone or something continuously

to wait in a concealed location and launch a surprise attack on a target
to be the person who leads something like an attack, campaign, movement, etc.

to engage in armed conflict
to bring soldiers into action for military service
to seriously injure or kill a person by shooting them, particularly someone who is defenseless
to fire upon an aircraft or another object with the intent of bringing it to the ground
to make a military observation or examination of an area to gather information, often in preparation for a future action

title: Verbs Related to Religion and Paranormal Phenomena

data.translation: to ask for divine favor or protection for a certain thing or person
to speak to God or a deity, often to ask for help, express gratitude, or show devotion

to give a religious speech, particularly in a church
to sincerely regret and turn away from wrongdoing, seeking forgiveness
to make something sacred through religious rituals
to purify and free from wrongdoing or guilt through a sacred process or ceremony
to fulfill a role in religious service or guidance, providing support and leadership within a community
to attempt to persuade someone to embrace Christianity as their faith
to initiate someone into the Christian faith through a special ceremony, often involving the use of water
to rescue someone from their sins
to deliver a religious speech, often with the intention of imparting moral or spiritual guidance
to donate ten percent of one's income, often to the church, as a religious commitment or financial support
to summon or invoke a spirit, demon, or supernatural force, often through rituals or magic
to call forth or summon a spirit, often through magical words, rituals, or incantations

to remove or expel an evil spirit from a person or place through the use of rituals, prayers, or supernatural methods
